intro: Mannopappus anomalus, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a perennial herb characterized by its basal rosette of blue-gray, hairy leaves and yellow composite flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant is adapted to harsh environments, featuring a deep root system and reduced leaf surface to minimize water loss. Its flowers are arranged in a head, typical of the Asteraceae family, and the plant produces small, wind-dispersed seeds. Mannopappus anomalus plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and provides nectar for pollinators in its native habitat.
